This story is about a lot of things, but mostly about idiots. So it needs saying from the outset that it’s always very easy to declare that other people are idiots, but only if you forget how idiotically difficult being human is. Especially if you have other people you’re trying to be a reasonably good human being for.

Because there’s such an unbelievable amount that we’re all supposed to be able to cope with these days. You’re supposed to have a job, and somewhere to live, and a family, and you’re supposed to pay taxes and have clean underwear and remember the password to your damn Wi-Fi. Sometimes we panic, because the bills need paying and we have to be grown-up and we don’t know how, because it’s so horribly, desperately easy to fail at being grown-up. One single really bad idea. That’s all it takes.

The police station on the eve of New Year’s Eve had an atmosphere akin to a sitcom set — a rather bizarre blend of tension and comedy perfectly encapsulated by the mismatched attire of its occupants. The young police officer, looking as if he had borrowed his uniform from a child’s dress-up box, sat across from an equally absurdly outfitted real estate agent whose jacket appeared several sizes too large. The absurdity was compounded by their conversation, where serious matters like hostage situations collided with the cheerful banter typical of a home-selling pitch. 

‘How’s tricks?’ she chirped, and one couldn’t help but picture the officer’s inner thoughts. He was clearly in a battle of wits with a person who had made their traumatic hostage experience an excuse for a bad real estate joke. The agent’s sunny disposition was so out of place one could imagine her casually discussing the market while a thief roamed free, all while displaying utter oblivion to the chaos surrounding them. Such moments, where the mundanity of life and the seriousness of duty mix with the exuberance of an overly enthusiastic sales pitch, forge a comedy of errors worthy of its own set of cautionary tales.

Our hearts are bars of soap that we keep losing hold of; the moment we relax, they drift off and fall in love and get broken, all in the wink of an eye. We’re not in control. So we learn to pretend, all the time, about our jobs and our marriages and our children and everything else. We pretend we’re normal, that we’re reasonably well educated, that we understand "amortization levels" and "inflation rates." That we know how sex works. In truth, we know as much about sex as we do about USB leads, and it always takes us four tries to get those little buggers in. (Wrong way round, wrong way round, wrong way round, there! In! ) We pretend to be good parents when all we really do is provide our kids with food and clothing and tell them off when they put chewing gum they find on the ground in their mouths. We tried keeping tropical fish once and they all died. And we really don’t know more about children than tropical fish, so the responsibility frightens the life out of us each morning. We don’t have a plan, we just do our best to get through the day, because there’ll be another one coming along tomorrow.

Sometimes it hurts, it really hurts, for no other reason than the fact that our skin doesn’t feel like it’s ours. Sometimes we panic, because the bills need paying and we have to be grown-up and we don’t know how, because it’s so horribly, desperately easy to fail at being grown-up. Because everyone loves someone, and anyone who loves someone has had those desperate nights where we lie awake trying to figure out how we can afford to carry on being human beings. Sometimes that makes us do things that seem ridiculous in hindsight, but which felt like the only way out at the time. One single really bad idea. That’s all it takes.

It’s the day before New Year’s Eve in a not particularly large town. A police officer and a real estate agent are sitting in an interview room in the police station. The policeman looks barely twenty but is probably older, and the real estate agent looks more than forty but is probably younger. The police officer’s uniform is too small, the real estate agent’s jacket slightly too large. The real estate agent looks like she’d rather be somewhere else, and, after the past fifteen minutes of conversation, the policeman looks like he wishes the real estate agent were somewhere else, too. When the real estate agent smiles nervously and opens her mouth to say something, the policeman breathes in and out in a way that makes it hard to tell if he’s sighing or trying to clear his nose.

“Just answer the question,” he pleads.

The Realtor nods quickly and blurts out:

“How’s tricks?”

“I said, just answer the question!” the policeman repeats, with an expression common in grown men who were disappointed by life at some point in their childhood and have never quite managed to stop feeling that way.

“You asked me what my real estate agency is called!” the Realtor insists, drumming her fingers on the tabletop in a way that makes the policeman feel like throwing objects with sharp corners at her.

“No I didn’t, I asked if the perpetrator who held you hostage together with—”

“It’s called House Tricks! Get it? Because when you buy an apartment, you want to buy from someone who knows all the tricks, don’t you? So when I answer the phone, I say: Hello, you’ve reached the House Tricks Real Estate Agency! HOW’S TRICKS?”

Obviously the Realtor has just been through a traumatic experience, has been threatened with a pistol and held hostage, and that sort of thing can make anyone babble. The policeman tries to be patient. He presses his thumbs hard against his eyebrows, as if he hopes they’re two buttons and if he keeps them pressed at the same time for ten seconds he’ll be able to restore life to its factory settings.

"So, you’re telling me you held up a bank?" asked Frank, his eyebrows raised to a point that looked like they might take off.  
"Well, sort of… more like I was just ‘borrowing’ some cash!" replied Tim with a sly grin, leaning back against the pub’s wooden bar. 
"Borrowing? You know they have terms for that, right? The cops call it ‘armed robbery’!" Frank chuckled, shaking his head. 
"But hear me out! It was a spontaneous thing! I didn’t prepare properly!" Tim insisted, slapping his palm on the bar for emphasis. 

"Spontaneous? Like you just woke up that morning and thought, ‘What could make my day better? A bank heist?’" Frank replied, taking a sip of his beer with a bemused smile. 
"Exactly! It’s just like they say: fortune favors the bold!" Tim responded, his voice dripping with sarcasm. 
"Right, and there’s nothing bolder than running into a bank waving a toy gun while wearing your pajamas!" Frank laughed, looking around to see if anyone had overheard.  
"Hey, they were comfy! Plus, no one expected the ‘Grocery Bandit’ to be wearing SpongeBob SquarePants lounge pants!" Tim exclaimed, adding a hand gesture to emphasize his daring outfit choice.  

"So, what was your escape plan? You didn't seriously think you could just waltz out of there, did you?" Frank asks, still incredulous.  
"Of course! I mean, who reads the fine print on being a criminal?" Tim said, rolling his eyes dramatically. "I didn’t think there were going to be repercussions!" 
"Well, spoiler alert: there are! What did you do? Trip on the way out?" Frank snorted, nearly choking on his beer.  
"Almost! I just ran up to the door, got scared, and… well, I might have barged into an open house instead and held people hostage by mistake!" 
"Wait, what? You ended up with a bunch of prospective buyers? That’s pretty bold! Surely they wanted to drop some cash, too!" Frank replied, slapping the bar for dramatic effect.  
"To ask me about the financing rates!" Tim retorted, rolling his eyes. "As if I’d have that info off the top of my head in the middle of a hostage situation!"  
"Ah, yes! Good job in holding demure hostage negotiations. ‘Excuse me, can I interest you in a 30-year mortgage while you kick back in my living room?’" Frank mocked, causing Tim to burst into laughter, shaking his head.  
"Let’s just say real estate was definitely not my strong suit!" Tim admitted with a sheepish grin.

It’s 2023, and somehow the idea of ‘adulting’ has become the new Olympic sport. Forget about athletic prowess; it’s all about how many bills you can juggle while pretending to thrive in a professional environment that feels, let’s be real, more like a poorly run circus with nothing but clowns and ineffective management. Sometimes I wonder if I should’ve trained harder for my role as an adult, perhaps with a series of intense workshops titled ‘How to Pretend You Know What You’re Doing in Life.’ Surely, they could cover essential topics like the art of nodding sagely while having absolutely no idea how taxes work.

I mean, who really needs to know the difference between a W-2 and a 1099 anyway? Just label them all as ‘extremely complicated pieces of paper that contribute to my slow existential crisis’ and hand them over to a confused-looking accountant who should also be wearing a ‘Help Me’ t-shirt as they sift through your receipts like a lie-detector test for adults.

Navigating social situations is another nail-biting sport that seems to require a PhD. You make small talk with someone about the weather, but let’s face it: no one wants to hear yet again that it’s unbearably rainy and you’re secretly considering building an ark just to escape your own basement. But then they ask about your plans for the weekend, and before you know it, you’re lying through your teeth about that ‘big networking event’ you were invited to, when really you plan to spend the entire weekend in your pajamas, binge-watching a show with a plot more complicated than the theories of relativistic physics.

As if this wasn’t enough pressure, social media has elevated our everyday lives to dangerously high stakes. Each meticulously curated image posted online stands as a testament against our chaotic realities, a showcase of the ‘perfect’ life that never fails to elicit jealousy and despair amongst the rest of us poor souls. You scroll through feeds of smiling families in matching outfits (who in their right mind dresses like that?) and dinner plates that look more like art installations than meals. Meanwhile, you’re lucky if you can find the soy sauce among the expired takeout containers in the fridge.

And let’s not forget self-care. Apparently, ‘self-care’ means buying a bath bomb that costs more than a small car and then feeling guilty for not managing to take that luxurious bath you always imagined while staring wistfully at the ceiling and pretending that your stress levels aren’t slowly resembling an erupting volcano. “Just a little burst of rage and confusion, darling! It’s character building!”

In the end, we all just want to be seen as competent players in the game we never signed up for, but every now and then, the absurdity of it all echoes loudly in our ears. “One single really bad idea,” we whisper in unison every time we contemplate our next social obligation or battle with the ever-dreaded electric bill. But hey, at least there’s always cookies.

The young policeman is feeling his forehead with his fingertips. He has a lump the size of a baby’s fist there.

“How did you get that?” the real estate agent asks, looking like she’d really prefer to ask How’s tricks? again.

“I got hit on the head,” the policeman grunts, then looks at his notes and says,

“Did the perpetrator seem used to handling firearms?”

The real estate agent smiles in surprise.

“You mean… the pistol?”

“Yes. Did he seem nervous, or did it look like he’d handled a pistol plenty of times before?”

The policeman hopes his question will reveal whether or not the real estate agent thinks the bank robber might have a military background, for instance. But the real estate agent replies breezily: “Oh, no, I mean, the pistol wasn’t real!”

The policeman squints at her, evidently trying to figure out if she’s joking or just being naive.

“What makes you say that?”

“It was obviously a toy! I thought everyone had realized that.”

The policeman studies the real estate agent for a long time. She’s not joking. A hint of sympathy appears in his eyes.

“So you were never… frightened?”

The real estate agent shakes her head.

“No, no, no. I realized we were never in any real danger, you know. That bank robber could never have harmed anyone!”

The policeman looks at his notes. He realizes that she hasn’t understood.

“Would you like something to drink?” he asks kindly.

“No, thank you. You’ve already asked me that.”

The policeman decides to fetch her a glass of water anyway.
